cardano-testnets/local-testnet.title: Creating a local testnet
cardano-testnets/local-testnet.description: A local testnet enables developers and projects building on Cardano to test new features or functionality prior to deployment on global testnet environments. While preview and pre-production environments benefit the wider developer community, a local testnet allows the execution of a hard fork in your own setup and subsequent testing of DApp behavior.

development-guidelines/index.description: Welcome to the developer resources section! Here you will find references to the resources that will help you with developing on Cardano.

development-guidelines/scalability/hydra.title: Hydra
development-guidelines/scalability/hydra.description: Hydra is a layer 2 scaling solution for Cardano rooted in peer-reviewed research that increases transaction throughput and ensures cost efficiency while maintaining rigorous security.

development-guidelines/scalability/mithr.title: Mithril
development-guidelines/scalability/mithr.description: Mithril is a stake-based multi-signature scheme that leverages the existing

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Transaction tutorials
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: A transaction is an event created, signed, and sent by a user to modify the

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Minting transactions
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: The ability to create and manage custom tokens is one of the distinguishing features of the Cardano blockchain. Minting refers to the process of 'producing new tokens, either as part of an initial coin offering (ICO) or ongoing token issuance'. Minting transactions enable users to generate or burn tokens according to predefined rules. This tutorial explores the details of minting transactions on Cardano.

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Multiple purposes
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: Cardano allows more complex transactions. So far you've seen various types of transactions: simple script, minting, staking, delegating, etc. But Cardano provides the flexibility to create more complex transactions and mix all the types of transactions needed. For example, adding metadata to minting transactions, or adding a staking component to a simple script transaction. This tutorial shows how to send a transaction with multiple purposes.

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Redelegation
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: This tutorial will show how to redelegate your stake to another stake pool. There can be multiple reasons to redelegate your stake, but the most common ones are:

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Staking transactions
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: Staking is a fundamental feature of Cardano, allowing you to earn rewards by delegating ada to stake pools. This tutorial shows how to delegate your ada to a stake pool, withdraw rewards, or stop delegating your ada if you decide to switch to another stake pool.

development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.title: Withdrawing transactions
development-guidelines/transaction-tutor.description: This part of the tutorial will demonstrate how easy it is to claim rewards using the cardano-cli. First, you need to ensure that you already have rewards available in your stake address. Check it with the following command:

evolution/about-hard-forks.title: About hard forks
evolution/about-hard-forks.description: The term hard fork describes a radical change in the blockchain: a change from

evolution/cardano-design-rationale.title: Design rationale
evolution/cardano-design-rationale.description: Cardano is an open source proof-of-stake blockchain project that began in 2015 to address existing blockchain challenges in the design and development of cryptocurrencies. It aims to provide a more balanced and sustainable ecosystem that better accounts for the needs of its users as well as other systems seeking integration.

evolution/eras-and-phases.title: Development phases and eras
evolution/eras-and-phases.description: This overview is based on CIP-59.

evolution/upgrades/allegra.title: Allegra
evolution/upgrades/allegra.description: Allegra was the Shelley protocol upgrade that introduced token locking support to enable various kinds of smart contract use cases.

evolution/upgrades/alonzo.title: Alonzo
evolution/upgrades/alonzo.description: Alonzo is the protocol upgrade implemented in September 2021, as part of the Goguen development phase. It built on top of transaction metadata, token locking, and native asset functionality to enable smart contract development.

evolution/upgrades/byron-to-shelley.title: Byron to Shelley
evolution/upgrades/byron-to-shelley.description: Cardano's Byron mainnet ran on the Ouroboros Classic consensus protocol. Cardano's Shelley mainnet transitioned to a decentralized network running on the Ouroboros Praos consensus protocol, which enabled more extended capabilities while also supporting the staking process with monetary rewards for ada holders and stake pool operators.

evolution/upgrades/mary.title: Mary
evolution/upgrades/mary.description: Mary is the Shelley protocol upgrade implemented in March 2021. It introduced

evolution/upgrades/valentine.title: Valentine (SECP)
evolution/upgrades/valentine.description: The Valentine (or SECP) upgrade is Cardano’s intra-era hard fork that followed the Vasil upgrade. Valentine was a small and focused semantic change to the ledger, which brought new built-in functions to Plutus to support SECP elliptic curves (ECDSA and Schnorr). Although an intra-era hard fork requires a hard fork combinator event, it does not change the ledger era, which means that this was an upgrade to the Babbage ledger era.

evolution/upgrades/vasil.title: Vasil
evolution/upgrades/vasil.description: Vasil is the protocol upgrade implemented in June 2022. Named after the late Bulgarian mathematician and prominent Cardano community member Vasil Dabov, the Vasil upgrade introduced five key mechanisms to improve the blockchain's performance: CIP-31 (reference inputs), CIP-32 (inline datums), CIP-33 (reference scripts), CIP-40 (collateral outputs), and diffusion pipelining.

explore-cardano/cardano-network/p2p-netw.title: Peer-to-peer (P2P) networking
explore-cardano/cardano-network/p2p-netw.description: Cardano nodes and the interactions between them are combined together within a

explore-cardano/concurrency.title: Understanding concurrency
explore-cardano/concurrency.description: Concurrency refers to the ability of different actors to perform work simultaneously without interfering with each other. In Cardano's Extended Unspent Transaction Output (EUTXO) model, transactions can be processed in parallel, enabling multiple operations without causing system failures. This approach enhances system throughput while maintaining the performance of individual operations.

explore-cardano/fee-structure.title: Cardano fee structure
explore-cardano/fee-structure.description: Cardano uses a transaction fee system that covers the processing and long-term

explore-cardano/monetary-policy.title: Cardano monetary policy
explore-cardano/monetary-policy.description: Cardano achieves true decentralization with the Voltaire development phase, which includes decentralized voting and

explore-cardano/parameter-guide.title: Cardano protocol parameters reference guide
explore-cardano/parameter-guide.description: Protocol parameters on Cardano are the various settings that define the blockchain's behavior. Some protocol parameters are stable and non-updatable while others can be adjusted to adapt to changing conditions over time.

explore-cardano/relevant-research-papers.title: Relevant research papers and specifications
explore-cardano/relevant-research-papers.description: Cardano is a third-generation blockchain platform that aims to provide the

explore-cardano/time.title: Time handling on Cardano
explore-cardano/time.description: Time is necessarily relative to every participant in the blockchain system and is critically important to support and maintain the safety properties of the Ouroboros consensus protocol. Minted blocks are expected to be propagated to all nodes in the system in a timely manner, so time requires the construction of a globally acceptable representation for consensus to be reached.

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.description: Welcome to the central hub for Cardano documentation. Here, you'll find content that describes and supports the features on both the Cardano mainnet and testnet environments.

learn/cardano-addresses.title: Cardano addresses
learn/cardano-addresses.description: The addresses are a blake2b-256 hash of the relevant verifying/public keys

learn/cardano-keys.title: Cardano keys
learn/cardano-keys.description: Cardano keys are asymmetric cryptography key pairs used for:

learn/chain-confirmation-versus-transact.title: Chain confirmation versus transaction confirmation
learn/chain-confirmation-versus-transact.description: When discussing Cardano, often-repeated questions are what is Cardano’s transaction time?, and how many network confirmations does Cardano require before a transaction goes through? The answers to these questions require a deeper look at the concepts of chain confirmation and transaction confirmation, and how these relate to the Ouroboros protocol.

learn/collateral-mechanism.description: The collateral mechanism is an important feature that has been designed to

learn/consensus-explained.title: Consensus explained
learn/consensus-explained.description: Consensus is the process of reaching a majority opinion by everyone involved in

learn/delegation.title: Delegation
learn/delegation.description: As Cardano is a proof of stake (PoS) system, owning ada not only allows you to

learn/eutxo-explainer.title: Extended UTXO model
learn/eutxo-explainer.description: The EUTXO handbook is now out! Deep dive into Cardano's EUTXO accounting model here.

learn/ouroboros-overview.title: Ouroboros overview
learn/ouroboros-overview.description: In mythology, Ouroboros (also, uroboros) is usually depicted as a snake (or sometimes a dragon) eating its own tail in a closed circle. The word Ouroboros itself derives from Ancient Greek, its literal meaning being 'tail eating' or 'tail devourer.'

learn/pledging-rewards.title: Pledging and rewards
learn/pledging-rewards.description: Pledging is an important mechanism that encourages the growth of a healthy

learn/stake-pools.title: Stake pools
learn/stake-pools.description: A stake pool is a reliable server node that focuses on ledger maintenance and holds the combined resources - the 'stake' - of various stakeholders in a single entity. Stake pools are responsible for processing transactions that will be placed in the ledger, as well as producing new blocks. Stake pools are at the core of Ouroboros, Cardano's proof-of-stake protocol.

learn/transaction-costs-determinism.title: Transaction costs and determinism
learn/transaction-costs-determinism.description: Cardano’s approach to price setting mainly relies on market demand over actual

new-to-cardano/cardano-tracking-tools.description: Since Cardano is a public blockchain ledger, it is possible to easily track all

new-to-cardano/what-is-a-cryptocurrency.title: What is a cryptocurrency?
new-to-cardano/what-is-a-cryptocurrency.description: A cryptocurrency is a digital asset, which is stored on the ledger and is

new-to-cardano/what-is-a-smart-contract.title: What is a smart contract?
new-to-cardano/what-is-a-smart-contract.description: Smart contracts on Cardano are simple programs often referred to as validator scripts in which users define custom logic. They are automatically executed by each Cardano node validating the transaction when the transaction attempts to move funds from the script's address. The address of each script is derived from the hash-sum of the compiled script.

operating-a-stake-pool/ranking.description: In the Daedalus wallet and Cardano Explorer, stake pools are ranked based on the

operating-a-stake-pool/SMASH.title: Pool metadata management
operating-a-stake-pool/SMASH.description: Stake pools are registered on-chain, and their on-chain data (such as information required to calculate rewards) is critical to the operation of the ledger. Stake pools also possess metadata that helps users make a rational choice of a stake pool to delegate to. This metadata is stored off-chain as it might reflect sensitive content, and such an approach allows for a degree of decentralized censorship.
